Process: Had three people interview me and an online test. Lot of conceptual questions. Overall a fair experience. I was later told that an offer was in the making and then they went completely silent. Strange!!! They could at least tell me why they ended up not making me an offer when they initially indicated that they would.
Interview Question 1: How will you go about designing something like google drive.

Process: I applied online through my university's career services website. I got a call the next day from a recruiter, who asked me some basic questions about school and work. From there he scheduled me immediately for an interview with a manager, and as soon as I was done he set me up for an interview with yet another manager. The interview was pretty easy, he asked me some basic questions on the software life-cycle and told me about what the job would entail. I really didn't get asked any technical questions, which I found very strange. I kind of lucked out that they were in a rush to fill this position, which is why I had 3 back to back phone interviews. The interviews took place on a Friday and I got the offer that Monday, I never even had to come into the office for an in person interview. My experience was definitely not the norm, I talked to other inters that summer who said the process took anywhere from 2 weeks to a month for them to get the offer.
Negotiation Phase: I accepted his initial offer, because I assumed it was a set amount for inters.
Interview Question 1: Describe the software development life-cycle. (Not a hard question, but it's the only remotely technical question I got asked)

Process: Two phone interviews (1 screening, 1 with the manager) followed by 1 in-person interview. The in-person interview was split into two stages with multiple managers. Managers were very nice and provided feedback, just went with a more experienced candidate.
Interview Question 1: Mostly about my background with some technical questions interspersed

Process: Great structured communication with hiring manager. Went through phone interview and second round in person with hiring manager and a panel of other managers/salesrep for one on one interviews.

HR was a little bit late in the game in my year, so I had a quick pre-screen interview and then 2 phone interviews with 2 hiring managers. Both lasted 20min. Wasn't hard, they asked me generic interview questions.
Fairly casual, behavioral questions such as "describe a challenging situation you have met."
Interview Question 1: If we want to enter the Latin America Market, how would you conduct the analysis

Process: Phone interview. one of the HR called me and had a phone interview for first round. Then second interview at the office with senior managers. They were very nice and the questions are not very hard.
Interview Question 1: what do you know about our firm?

Process: I had a phone interview and then was called in for an in-person interview. The interviewer didn't remember anything we had discussed on the phone. After the in-person interview, interviewer told me that interviewer wanted to bring me on but interviewer needed team approval, and that the team assistant would be in touch with me to schedule a meeting with the entire team. I emailed a week after the interview but received no response. After 3 weeks, I still had no heard anything. I emailed again and was finally told that the assistant would be in touch with me later that day. Assistant never contacted me. This was for an unpaid position.
Interview Question 1: What are my weaknesses?

Process: I applied for an inside sales position. I had a phone interview a month after applying and an in person a month later. Next round would have been video with London management. They were undergoing a reorg; wanted inside salespeople to manage the relationship and maximize revenue from existing client base. I applied online; heard back from them about a month later to set up a phone interview. That round was just screening and pretty rote stuff. I got a called for a second interview about 2 weeks later. That interview ended up occurring about 2 months after my application- the pace was slow. Second interview was with the MD I would report to. I thought it went well, was surprised to get a form "we've decided not to follow up with you" email from HR about 2 weeks later. The 3rd round would have been a video interview with London (department is run from there).
Interview Question 1: How do you deal with angry or upset clients?

Process: Do not recommend dealing with McGraw Hill Financial. Felt they were dishonest, used every chance to harass and discriminate. After interview weeks went by then asked for lots of references then said to hold on for long time, disappeared and after many more weeks heard staffers hired internally, disingenuous. Higher rated and bigger firms post outside only after internally. Ones I interviewed with said they were better, lol, seemed like coming off microsoft or mainframe because didn't understand today's stack or development. They asked about educational books and software, later checking McGraw Hill Education was sold. They became nasty, and started saying any education or background in software was bad, unbelievable. Look into them first, sold their books and educational software division but it kept the McGraw Hill name, and if you don't know that they'll turn real unpleasant. They're just S&P now. Skill level even of managers really weak, seemed like they brought in from offshore without credentials and they didn't like anyone with real skill. Said what they did was all new and everything else like experience didn't want to hear about, trying to move to 'straight through processing', haven't heard software put that way in decades. Checking they dropped 20 spots in rank and are about to fall off the fortune 500, in my humble opinion I wouldn't join them, seemed like sinking ship and I was glad to get out of their and after over a month after giving solid references was glad didn't get offer, had given up anyway. This is very true and genuine review.
Interview Question 1: Can you just program or is design and architecture good?  They said did agile.

Process: Received a call from HR. Interviewed with HR Contact, Manager, Director and VP
Interview Question 1: Where do you see yourself in 5 years

Process: Efficient with smart, nice people. Some tech-specific questions as well as understanding whether someone is a good team and cultural fit. Seeking ability and potential to learn over a specific skillset. This was back in the day before they became as corporate, so not sure what it's like now.
Interview Question 1: Mapping out the logic of an algorithm.

Process: The hiring manager inflated the appeal of the opportunity. Once I was on board, the nature of the work was more junior than promised, and there was less staff available than discussed. I later learned that others had the same experience when they were recruited. The background check took weeks and was excessive -- you just have to wait it out.
Negotiation Phase: As with most companies, do your research, push for as much compensation as you can because once they have you, raises are tiny.  Also, I had 3 weeks vacation with my then-current employer and they matched it.  Get it in writing.
Interview Question 1: How do you attach metrics to your work.

Process: Final performance review handled over conference call. It was the 1st time it had been handled this way and allowed for more people to participate which gave me broader feedback. I really felt it was very useful.
Interview Question 1: What would I want passed along to future employees?

Process: 4 interviews in total - the hiring manager, 2 peers and the head of operations. All one-on-one with one final meeting with the hiring manager to round up. It took a number of weeks to get the interviews but ultimately the decision was made rather quickly.
Interview Question 1: product management specific methodology questions

Process: Was reached out to on LinkedIn by a 3rd party recruiter, as they had trouble filling the role. 3rd party recruiter connected me with the internal recruiter, who got me setup with a phone screen on the team. Did one 1 hour phone screen, then they scheduled me for a follow-up video interview with others on the team. Finally, they flew me to corporate HQ in NYC for an 8 hour day of interviews with HR, VPs over the role, team members, and the hiring manager.
Negotiation Phase: There's a "fixed" schedule of vacation time depending on company tenure and level, but you can negotiate a little more vacation starting out.  It will be a good idea to have multiple offers at other companies at the same time, as recruiters and hiring managers are strongly incentivized to keep salaries down to the bare minimum, and they may well walk away to a cheaper candidate if you stick to your guns.
Interview Question 1: You will have a lot of tasks with changing priorities and schedules.  How do you handle this in your day-to-day work to ensure that deadlines are met?

Process: Applied through a referral. Process took 3 weeks. Had two back to back 30 minute video interviews. I also had an in person meeting with one of S&P globals credit raters.
Interview Question 1: Walk me through your resume

Process: 1. Phone Interview 2. 1:1 Interview with Direct Reporting Manager 3. 1:1 Interview with #2's boss 4. 1:1 Interview with #3's boss
Negotiation Phase: Negotiated on more vacation days. But after the 1st year, they re-engaged on the agreed upon time.
Interview Question 1: Why do you want to leave your company?

Process: I've been introduced by an agency. First interview was with the hirimg manger and a couple of peers. Final interview was with the head of recruiting.
Negotiation Phase: I asked for some more dollars and extra vacation time and was able to get it based on my prior exprience.
Interview Question 1: How would you handle a hiring manger who doesn't want to work with you and would prefer to use an outside agency?

Process: Spoke to several managers after HR
Interview Question 1: Where would you expect to be in 3 to 5 years?

Process: 1. Phone Interview with HR Recruiter 2. Phone Interview with Hiring Manager 3. In person Interview with VP of HR

I thought the interview process was great. It started with a phone interview, that was really a get-to-know me and them session. They told me about what they did, what the magazines consisted of and what my general duties would be. Then they asked if I would be interested in coming to the office to see the facility and meet the sr. managing editor. I scheduled that, and met with him, we talked about me most of the time and how I could apply my current skills to this job. They walked me through the publications I would be in charge of and gave me a tour of the building. Three days later I got a phone call from the news director in NYC, who tested me on a few things over the phone and asked me how I felt about my ability to do the job well. I knew shortly after that call that I would be sent an offer. But, they went out of their way to make me feel welcome and I felt they sincerely wanted to know about me -- not just have another body to fill a seat.
Interview Question 1: Unexpected: Why are you leaving your current position?

Process: Took forever, made constant trips back to NYC, only to have the job given to a friend of the person I would have been working for. Even went into NYC (90 minutes commute) to arrive once and get told that the person I was supposed to interview with wouldn't be able to meet with me, so I would need to reschedule for another day. Which I did (because I was in the top three for the position).
Submitted clips and resume. Interviewed with senior editors in New York and Washington.
Negotiation Phase: I was able to get moving costs from Boston to Washington covered.
Interview Question 1: Tell us about a mistake you made on a story and how you handled it.

Process: Very Intensive for the level of position. Phone interview with 3rd party HR representative is a formality with standard canned questions. There were multiple in person interviews. Your knowledge of the financial service industry is important. You will be sent to a 3rd party offsite (somewhat sketchy small strip mall office) to confirm you are a US citizen.
Interview Question 1: Q:  What would you do if you have multiple High Priority Issues going on at once that you are not sure how to solve?

Process: Excellent, fast, good information provided about the job, Mgmt. knowledgeable and experienced. HR informative and timely with updates.
Negotiation Phase: Went through head hunter, negotiations not directly with company. At point were with company, was given impression of more potential for increase than available by company standards. Negotiate base pay on front end, don't count on bonuses.
Interview Question 1: Typical questions on experience and how it relates to the position.

Process: the whole process was very long and between the initial phone interview and the 1:1 it took them a very long time. When I was finally called in for the face-to-face they said they had already filled the position. Not too sure why they called me in at all... Well the hiring manager mentioned she had just started looking for someone. After the one hour long interview she said she was going to see if she can find someone else to interview me ( so that I meet with less people on the second interview) and then she came back and said no one was available.

Initial phone screen with HR which was very thorough in that they asked about commuting (can you get here from there) and if I was "in process" for any other job at any other company. The second interview was with the business unit manager, which I could see I wasn't connecting with and at one point seemed argumentative. I knew I was sunk when he cut the interview short to go to a meeting, and said someone will be in touch. What bothers me most is I never heard from them, not even the beige e-mail stating "thanks, but no thanks."
Interview Question 1: Why do you want to leave your present job?

Process: This is a dual location position where the job is split between Central NJ and NYC. I went in for an interview with the M&A Manager and Corporate Controller for the I/C Senior Financial Analyst.
Interview Question 1: The first person was pleasant enough but I barely could get a word in and the interview took longer than expected. Met the second person who seemed disinterested immediately.  It was so awkward as I could tell she just wanted to get back to work. I had to actually ask her if she wanted to know anything additional or go over my resume. I feel like I was judged before I had a chance to speak and did not feel like I had a fair chance from the beginning.  Their loss.

Process: mostly behavioural type and technical accounting focusing on past job performance, the value you added and challenges you came across and how it was handled. Interview with four individual most whcih worked for the company for more than 10 years and very well knowledgeable.
Interview Question 1: Tell me about yourself

Process: Quick and efficient; they had an interviewing team that represented both HR and business lines; interviewers were on time and efficient; logistics were well coordinated; feedback was provided at the end of each interivew
Interview Question 1: Pretty standard questions but with more depth - tried to understand my motivation

Process: Straight forward process with HR initial interviews and hiring manager(s) conducts follow up.
Stay professional.
Why Decline: I live 300 miles away. They would not negotiate salary or relocation benefits.
Interview Question 1: Why do you want to work for McGraw-Hill?

Process: I got hired as an intern, so I didn't have to go through the full rounds of interviews. Typically you meet with HR, then 2 to 3 people interview you from the team.
Interview Question 1: NA - mostly fit questions.

Process: When I interviewed with them it was for a contract position and they were welcoming and informative as to what they were looking for and expecting. They guided you for success.
Interview Question 1: They concentrated the questions regarding your knowledge of finance, accounting, and systems.

Process: Went through their first round of phone interviews, it was about an hour long. Two people interviewed me the first person asked behavioral questions while the second person steered more towards technical questions. The interview was rather straight forward but they were very friendly.
Interview Question 1: What is Capital Expenditure?

Process: Was contacted by recruiter saying I was found in their internal system and was asked to set up a time. I set up a time to interview and then the recruiter never got back to me. My best guess is that the position was filled, which is why I wasn't contacted back. However, it would have been common courtesy for the recruiter to let me know instead of leaving me hanging. Left a poor impression on me regarding S&P's reputation.
Short and your are a temp to perm for a long time until everyone else quits.
Interview Question 1: Name a time you had to improvise to help someone.

Process: Was contacted for a 5-10 min. phone interview in order for the company to gain a general knowledge of who I was. Then a 30 min. phone interview with a superior. Was then asked to come in for a formal interview with 3 executives.
Interview Question 1: What was one hardship that you faced in a previous position, and how did you overcome it?

Process: 4 back to back 30 min sessions talking about role Managers will go into depth of asset classes as much as you want them to. Be prepared to answer any simple capital markets questions such as calculating bonds or how to calculate something.
Interview Question 1: How do you calculate NAV

Process: Although the title will initially be consultant this will be an executive managing director position or potentially global head after 1-2 yrs. Initially, it will be to conduct research/due dil. to present to board for a new division & if approved managing/directing to add momentum and educate market place/create new strategic partnerships.
Interview Question 1: How would I create a commercial road map and go about conducting a market analysis?

Process: It was fairly straightforward. I found the exchanges with the recruiter to be very pleasant and informative. The 1:1 with the hiring manager was a great conversation. However, the company HR manager was fairly reserved and not necessarily a great ambassador for the company. The interview felt less like an interrogation based on qualifications than maybe what someone might feel interviewing for a private club. I would say the culture is extremely conservative.
Interview Question 1: Where did you learn your management style?

Process: The interview process was considerately done; I received an email 2 business days before the proposed date and time and was asked to confirm my availability. The first phone interview was performed by the executive recruiter - they were polite and sociable which help to alleviate some of the potential stress. The recruiter studied my resume and knew it well so there were no questions like, 'tell me about yourself' - the questions were future-oriented, i.e: 'What is to you for your next position?' and 'How do you envision your role?' After about 20 minutes of a fairly free-formed discussion, the interviewer explained their background and the general requirements for the position. I asked a few questions and the interviewer confirmed that I was a candidate for the next interview round. The second phone interview was scheduled, and confirmed, 2 days later with a C-level executive manager; I was asked to spend about 15 minutes of uninterrupted time discussing: 1) my 'elevator pitch', 2) what is it that I like to do? 3) what am I proud of? and 4 ) a particular challenge. Subsequently, the executive manager explained who they were, their high-level goals for the organization and the goals and objectives of the open position. I asked a few questions and we ended the interview. The next day, I sent a 'thank you' email in the early AM and by midday the company confirmed that I would was not going to continue on to the next round of onsite interviews.
Interview Question 1: The interviewers use the technique of 'free-form' and uninterrupted discussions to not only see how well you can articulate your abilities but they are also trying to assess if you will be good fit into, what appears to be, a very close-knit and small organization.

Process: 30 Minute screening call with their recruiter that asked some technical knowledge and experience questions regarding the stock markets. Then as in-person interview with hiring manager and one of his peers. They had a list of customer service related questions and also tested my skills on the computer including an Excel case study.
Interview Question 1: Show me on the computer where to delete cookies.

Process: Video conference interview with the product team leader. 1hr. Described existing team, recent acquisitions and corporate culture. Discussed ideas for enhancements to desktop and mobile application products to accelerate active usage for high growth target segments.
Interview Question 1: Describe new features and AI that could be added to the mobile application to grow usage and potential audience?

Process: Applied through school. First round was tech interview on campus, asking to design an application to show different statistics, then asked questions about the design (how do you know it was good, what makes the design better than others ect.ect.) also asked about workflows. They then had an interview in New York, where I meet with 3 different people on the BA team. One of them grilled and critisized my application, one of them asked to describe a different app that I enjoyed using and why i liked it, one of them was just a general conversation to see if i was a good fit for the company.
Interview Question 1: What makes a good Design?

Process: 3 rounds of the interview process. S&P Global came to my career fair where I handed my resume. I was called for an in-person interview that consisted of UI design and research, data analysis and testing related questions. The next interview was more of a personality test followed by a technical round of interview.
Interview Question 1:
Draw a workflow chart given the requirements
Write SQL statements
Create test plans

Process: First I went through a routine phone screening. The second part of the Interview processes consisted of an interview with the business intelligence team manager. Finally, in the last phase of the interview process, I met with two sr. level Business Intelligence Analysts and followed up with the hiring manager.
Interview Question 1: Q: Why do you feel you are qualified for this job?

Process: I was contacted by a recruiter months after submitting my resume for the position. In fact, I didn't even remember the position and had to do some research to find the job again. The first interview was over the phone. The second was at the office with two members of the team. My biggest complaint is the lack of feedback. After following up I was told that I would hear something back with regards to the position. I never did. I was told that I would know the status by the end of the week. That has came and gone. For such a big company I would have figured that they would give some kind of feedback regardless if you have received the job or not. Minus that everything else was fine.
Interview Question 1: Tell me how you would fit into this position?

Process: Not to lengthy, Essay test was given which made no sense, took too long to complete the process and the negotiation and offer roll out. HR was very slow. background check too very long time.
Interview Question 1: Whats your career aspiration

Process: Easy process and role explained for very clear though the time taken was too long. Management was slow in making decision but once selected it went very smooth. Onboarding process was well organised.
Interview Question 1: Tell me about yourself

Process: I applied for the job online and received an email about two weeks later to schedule a short phone interview. That interview consisted mostly of screening questions about where I lived and if I would need visa sponsorship. Then I set up an in-person interview the following week. I met with two editorial managers for the interview, which lasted between 20-30 minutes. I heard back from the company regarding the position about a week and a half later.
Interview Question 1: General questions about experience. Have you ever had issues with editing a certain writer? What do you know about us? What experience do you have with content management systems?

Process: Three rounds of phone calls. The first with HR specialist, the second with the hiring manager, and the third an interview with a hiring panel. Other questions were about the possibility of relocating and knowledge of the company's main businesses.
Interview Question 1: General questions about skills- how your skills match with the job description and professional interest - how does the position align with your future plans and interests.

Process: They said they were looking to fill the position quick. They seemed really interested in hiring me and said they would follow up the week after the interview either way but I haven’t heard a thing. My status is in “in process”. I took time out of my busy schedule and accommodated them for all of these interviews and I get radio silence in return. Shame on this company. Don’t rush me to interview and ghost on me.
Interview Question 1: Tell me about yourself.
Interview Question 2: Tell me about your organizational skills.

Process: It took a long time - four interviews with four different people. A lot of hard questions were asked, as this particular division did not trust its employees and so screened very carefully. One of the reasons why it took so long is because there was a lot of reorganization going on, and that impacted who I would be working under. In retrospect, it took too long, and was a sign that something was amiss in this department. I've learned since to go with my gut regarding how I feel about the interview process, because it often mirrors actually working there.
Negotiation Phase: Done on the phone with a McGraw-Hill recruiter.
Interview Question 1: Who is your toughest critic?

Process: Initial call from recruiter along with a length phone screen, periodic touch bases in between. Two more interviews
Interview Question 1: Tell me about yourself

Process: Process was one round consisting of two half hour video conference calls each with a different manager. Both the interviewers were pleasant and overall I was very satisfied with the interview process. The interview questions were mostly behavioral based with only technical questions, but no coding. The day after the interview, the recruiter contacted me with an offer, which I accepted.
Interview Question 1: Standard behavioral questions i.e: what do you know about the company, why S&P, etc.
Interview Question 2: Difference between a class and object

Process: Best interview every, interview by recruiter and them background check
Interview Question 1: Interview was very layed back

Process: The first round was a non technical phone interview. The second round was a video call followed by coding and theory questions online. The overall process took 2 and half weeks.
Interview Question 1: Basic OOPS concepts and detecting the error questions

Process: Somewhat straight-forward, nothing out of the ordinary. I would say interview was relatively easy.
Negotiation Phase: I told them my minimum requirement and was offered exactly the same, since it was 20% raise for me, I took the offer

Process: MHF's recruiter contacted me after seeing an old job profile of mine and telling me how thoroughly impressed she was with our conversation and my skills. From there, I quickly finished two additional interviews in a matter of days with senior staff within HR/learning followed by another one with a member of the UK office. They were good at first about being communicative about next steps and consistently told me I was one of the top candidates for the job. They even gave me a deadline by which they would have a decision. I was weighing other job offers (which they knew), so the deadline mattered to me. They blew past their own deadline by two days, and when I followed up, I am told about a sudden need for more interviews the following day (I was happy to oblige because I really wanted the job). The recruiter and the hiring manager reiterated that I am "definitely on the shortlist" and they were "definitely interested" in me. They were definitely building up my expectations. After finishing this last round on Thursday of last week, I was assured that I would have an answer by EOD Friday. I knew I had put my best foot forward in every interview, and felt pretty good about my prospects (or had at least set a very high bar for my competition to clear). Around 4:30pm on Friday, I hear from the recruiter. He told me that I didn't get the job (unfortunate, but not earth-shattering). However, the reason wasn't that I wasn't good enough (he said "you were the candidate to beat"), but because the hiring team had decided to hire no one and instead go back to the drawing board for the position entirely. Further, they would bring in a whole new candidate pool, which meant I would have to start interviewing all over. While I recognize that nothing was promised, what a way to make a prospective employee feel used! While MHF is welcome to carry out its hiring choices and its crises of conscience, their boorish, unprofessional and bait-and-switch behavior here is not what I expected from a well-respected company. After this experience, I'm glad I don't work there!
Interview Question 1: Why are you a fit for this position?
Interview Question 2: What's your style for working with subject matter experts?

Process: Sent in my resume through their website, and was soon contacted by HR for a quick phone-interview. Asked me mostly generic questions (Tell me about yourself/your resume, why do you want this position, why do you want to work for McGraw-Hill). After, I was contacted to come in for a face-to-face interview. I met first met with the director of my department, and then I met with the co-director. They both asked me standard behavioral questions (tell me about a time when you had to work as as a team and there was a problem, etc). The only technical question I was asked was with the initial interview with the Director-- He just gave me a few simple scenarios and asked how each action would affect the three financial statements.
Negotiation Phase: No negotiating, I was given the same intern rate all McGraw-Hill interns got.
Interview Question 1: Say we take buy a bond, walk me through how that would affect the balance sheet, income statement, and statement of cash flows.

Process: I received an email from one of the recruiters saying that I have been selected to have a quick phone chat the next day. I emailed back to say you can reach at 3:00 pm tomorrow. However, it has been passed 3:00 pm and I haven't received any phone calls from them, even no emails replied to me. I am so surprised at this situation, didn't expected this would happen, and could anyone tell me what should I do now? Btw, I looked up on the glassdoor interview reviews, they do have negative comments about the long-run process of their recruiter team, however, I didn't see any comments talking about the recruiters forgot or ignored the phone time. Anyone? Anyone can help?
Interview Question 1: They didn't call me!! Unbelievable!

Process: Started with a 15 minute phone screen, proceeded to do 2 more 30+ minute interviews over the phone, as well as an hour and a half interview over Zoom. After 2 months of this process and all the time given to them they did not even give the courtesy of saying they went with another candidate. It’s been 3 months since initial contact and have been given no update, even after reaching out.
Interview Question 1: What are some reasons you would like to have this job.

Process: It was a phone interview. The lady was very nice and supportive. She asked minimum questions and preferred to listen to a candidate. They promised to call back and schedule the second interview. But nobody called. It is better not to know right away if you fit this position or not than to hope further and look forward to next interview
Interview Question 1: What was the role on previous job?

Job Title: S&P Dow Jones Indices Index Development
Process: They emailed me to say they wanted to set up a phone Interview, phone interview was roughly 30 minutes long, and they offered me the position a few day later. Process was pleasant and everyone I talked to was very nice.
Interview Question 1: Technical skills with excel

Process: I spoke to a person who recently went through the program and was moving into a different position. Overall it was a good experience. I learned about the product, the company and the opportunity. I definitely would recommend applying if you have a strong financial background.
Interview Question 1: Why finance? What is an annual report? Talk about a time in which you made an error how did you handle it? How did you handle a difficult team member? What is something that you have been following on the news. Talk about what you know about the position and the company.

Process: The first step was a vanilla phone screen. After than I was invited to the office for an in person interview. The office reminded me of offices from a decade ago. The interviewer was not versed in Statistics at all, and asked strange questions. There were 4 interviews all together and most of them were in-inspiring. One of the interviews was a "technical" interview with someone in their NY office. He googled obscure questions (literally during interview) that he didn't have context for, and were ancillary. It was a poor match. The interviewer seemed inexperienced and didn't even follow up after the on-site.
Interview Question 1: Standard HR questions.

Process: I applied online with my grad school. HR called for a quick screening to make sure I am interested in the job. I then had a quick phone call with director of the department. Last, I had in person series of interviews with each member of the team. This lasted a long time, but I found was effective in understanding the company and team.
Interview Question 1: If you have differences between what you believe and the Product Managers or clients belief, what would you do?

Process: Super day was 2 30minute interviews. All technical questions. Looked on this website and saw that the questions were behavioral, but they've changed them to all technical. know your accounting ratios and what they're used for, and know the debt ones specifically
Interview Question 1: What is working capital?

Process: I had a great experience interviewing with the company. I applied online, received a phone call days later and then an email shortly after. After scheduling the interview I received a second email consisting of topics to review that will be expected to be covered during the interview, which I loved. My interview was an hour-long virtual interview split into two half-hour interviews with different interviewers. The first interview was technical and the second was behavioral, of course. Each interviewer I spoke to made me feel very comfortable throughout the entire process. They both displayed their sense of humor as well. Overall, the communication with the company was great. They responded to my emails extremely quickly.
Interview Question 1: What's the difference between a class and an object?
Interview Question 2: Why are you interested in this position?

Process: There were two rounds of phone interviews both had mostly behavioral questions like, why DMRS, why credit, followed by a brain teaser at the end. Really straightforward besides the brain teaser.
Interview Question 1: What skill sets do you provide to the team?

Process: Straightforward interview process, they asked about my background in energy and writing, had an interview with HR, then with my manager. They asked some basic questions about my writing skills and knowledge of energy industry and a writing sample.
Interview Question 1: Tell me about some of the energy-related content you've written at your previous role

Process: The interview process was smooth and the interviews went well. The process could have been a bit more professional and I was all by myself and there was no travel or accommodation assistance provided. However, there were multiple follow-ups I had to do with the HR for the interview and for the offer.
Interview Question 1: General background and my experience. Involved some SQL and project related questions

Process: Not to hard. Simple questions given they didn't want to continue beyond phone screen because of visa sponsorship. The HR round was easy and we both thought it was a great fit but after an hour when I brought the sponsorship up they were not willing to move ahead under any circumstances. Cannot blame them. Seemed to be a nice company with nice people.

I applied online in November, received an interview request in December, interviewed a week or two later, then received my offer in January. The interview process was two 30 minute back-to-back behavioral interviews through video call with some technical questions asked.
Interview Question 1: Tell us about a time you dealt with conflict.

Process: The process was simple, composed of 3 phone calls (1 pre-screening with HR, 1 with the hiring manager, 1 with Senior manager). Standard questions were asked - motivation, working style, and about working remotely.
Interview Question 1: What is your work style?

Process: Smooth process with strong feedback, very welcoming and engaging in the interview. Casual start with eased nerves, then went straight to the point. Great location to work in. I went in for 3 interview stages, first was a telephone call, second was a 1-1 interview in the office and third was an interview with the senior manager. This helped get a great feel about the role, team and any further questions I had about the role.
Interview Question 1: Why do you want to work for S&P Global?

Process: It was wonderful excellent, time consuming but learning experience for sure. Was overwhelmed adn enthusiastic about the whole process and company's way of conducting such a grand interview process so easily and efficiently
Interview Question 1: Internships

Process: Phone Interview - technical Round : went for 1 hour , grilled every aspect of Oracle PL SQL Face to face Interview - Technical Round: Question based on Resume, skill set and past experience. HR Interview - Compensation Negotiation
Interview Question 1: Related to ORACLE and Support Processes

Process: Started off by sending an application through to S&P Global, heard back within a few days to arrange a phone interview with HR. The interview was a 30 minute conversation with basic competency questions - strengths/ weaknesses etc, and questions around why I wanted to work for the company and the chosen role. Was briefed on the role as well, gave an insight on what you would do on a day to day basis. Whilst I didn't get the offer, it took them well over a month for them to get back to me regarding the interview which was slightly annoying but somewhat expected as it takes time to hear back (not usually 5 weeks).
Interview Question 1: What are some of your strengths and weaknesses?
Interview Question 2: Why would you like to work for us

Process: From one office in Asia. Submitted a resume and coverletter both one page in A4. Asked basic and formal question which is expected from a typical rating and research company.
Interview Question 1: Why S&P

Process: Took about a month to get back to me after applying, they had me do a interview on hirevue? They never got to me after applying, Took about a month to get back to me after applying, they had me do a interview on hirevue? They never got to me after applying,
Interview Question 1: Why did you apply for this role, what are your strengths etc. They were very general questions. Took about a month to get back to me after applying, they had me do a interview on hirevue? They never got to me after applying,

Process: Not sure if I described the duration of the interview properly. Regardless, I was referred to a position with McGraw-Hill in 2009. I interviewed with someone from their office in Columbus, OH over the phone and was subsequently interviewed 1:1 with the person under whom I would be working. The person I interviewed with and other employees at the office seemed friendly enough. As much as I wanted the position, I was not offered it.
Interview Question 1: Could you elaborate on how your work experience as listed on this resume?

Process: I applied through a posting on the careers website of my university, they replied quickly even though I applied late inviting me to a video interview. I had a video interview through hirevue, in which you dont interact with anyone and you only get one opportunity to film each response of three minutes, of which there are 10 in total
Interview Question 1:
Video interview was a little strange, 10 questions, first five asked me to confirm degree details, languages and stuff like that. Then the next five where:

1. What do you know about MGHF and SP Dow Jones Indices?

2. Why did you apply to the program?

3. What makes you think you're suited to the program?

Cant remember others

Process: it consists of 4 rounds.ie online written test,two technical,one hr round.its too difficult to clear technical rounds.most of the candidates are rejected in that only.final hr round was some easy.securing job in snp global is not a joke
Interview Question 1: personal,n subject related questions

Process: Recruiter called to ask some questions and mention would get back if I was shortlisted. I got a call for face to face interview about 1 week later. (The experience was fine till then) On the day of f2f interview, the hiring manager was late for 15min (I was put in a meeting room, not knowing what happened). When she finally arrived, she called me by the wrong name (obviously took the wrong resume) and she went back to take my resume. It was another another 8 min before she came back. During the interview, there were times she just yawned and look out of the window (very rude). Obviously, I wasn't expecting any progress with her.....after the experience
Interview Question 1: Why you want to move to financial industry?

Process: behavioral interview- standard qualitative questions walk me through your resume
Interview Question 1: why are you interested in this position and how does your previous experience relate?

Process: Had a phone interview followed by an interview with the hiring manager and finally the department's director. Interview with the director was very detailed. Relaxed interview, more of ongoing conversation.
Interview Question 1: Why did you apply for this role and what do you hope to gain from it?

Process: It took them 2 months to call me for an interview, It was skype interview . The attitude of interviewers was good, but I forgot to answer one simple question and they laugh at me ironically. A really Bad experience that was. HR was really helpful, she called & took my 15 to 20 min to explain me whats the process of company & how interview will be conduct & what should i prepare for interview.
Interview Question 1:
SQL joins count of a table in SQL.
What is non-functional testing
Asked about scrum, it's roles.
Asked some management level questions, that if one of my colleagues is not working properly due to his home problem & you have some work which is pending due to him what will you do.

Process: Brilliant. Quick and direct. First phone call, cleared lots of questions that were generic. Everything was done in an hour and I received an offer that evening. Couldn't be any better.
Interview Question 1: Where do you see yourself in a year?

Process: It is a 5 step process. 1. HR - Telephonic interview 2. HR - Personal 3. Tech - written 4. Tech - manager interview 5. Tech - Director interview Overall bigger than what would be usually for a company but since they pay good, they deserve to take their time in hiring.
Interview Question 1: Future prospects

Process: It is a video interview which consists about 6 questions. You have time for practising before the formal interview and time for preparing before answering the questions. Some questions look similar but with little differences.
Interview Question 1: Why do you think you fit the company

Process: I applied online and got invitation to video interview a few days afterwards. The first round is video interview. All questions are behavioral. More about the motivation and how much you know about the company and program.
Interview Question 1: What interests you to apply for this program?

Process: 1 Telephonic/Skype Interview as suitable , which I would jude as medium difficulty . If you clear it , there will be atleast one 1F2F interview too. (Didn't reach F2F round)
Interview Question 1: Basic OOPS

Process: Two Group discussion round on current topic. Read current topics and you will be able to crack. One Written test (Aptitude and reasoning and accounting Questions) And one personal Managerial round
Interview Question 1: Questions related to Accounting

Process: When it comes to the process It was Well-manage and on time. It was a great experience to be exact. Though it was a hard one but worth it.
Interview Question 1: How did you know the company?

Process: Very standard interview with potential boss.
Interview Question 1: Nothing really, standard questions.

Process: Very relaxed phone interview and then two panel interviews. You do a very basic finance test in one of the interviews. They mainly want someone who is willing to learn and wants plenty of training opportunities (which is what they offer). Overall great company to work for to learn lots about finance.
Interview Question 1: Why S&P? How would you provide good client service? Experience of handling a bad client?

Process: 1)Telephone, Interview 2) Face to face interview- three 30 minute interviews and a written test ( finance based questions on market capitalisation bonds, where cap exp is found on a balance sheet, how to calculate EBITDA margin, what B means in investment (beta)
Interview Question 1:
Give me a time when you handled an irritated customer/customer complaint 

Why S&P Capital IQ

What do you know about S&P Capital IQ

Why this position

What do you think you need to succeed in this position? What qualities

How do you prioritise?

Give me an example of when you worked in a team?

How do you deal with clashes within a team?

What do you think will be the main challenges facing you in this role at the beginning?

How did you hear about the job?

Give me an interesting story you have read this week?

What sources do you use for information?

Why the degree that you have studied?

Process: Starts with an aptitude test, then a small HR round, then again a written test on finance, Then manager's round and finally directors round. Generally the process takes 3-5 days, but in my case all rounds were done the same day.
Interview Question 1: What is difference between straddle and Strangle?

Process: Firstly, I applied on their website. Then got a call from their HR dept for on call interview, after shortlisting they called me for CBT. After clearing the test I was called for interview.
Interview Question 1: What are your future goals?
Interview Question 2: Why do you want to join S & P Globals?

Process: HR ask me if i was interested. Question about my background. 1) Interview with 2 Directors. Question about how evoluate the market and what is my view for the short term (forecast). Question regarding Structured credit product (CDO, RMBS ..). How to analyse it. 2) Case study with 2/3 Directors: show your understanding of product and their rating methodology. 3) Final interview with a Senior director to explain how the business work and what i would like to do. 4) HR for administrative stuff.
Negotiation Phase: No negotiation because of the contract. Fixed term contract.
Interview Question 1:
Case study: show your understanding of product and their rating methodology.
Take some time to read all criteria, analyse and to prepare a presentation.

Process: Three phases. First an online interview through Hirevue. The second interview is a two call interview, with a more technical insight about what you are going to do and technical questions about finance and accounting. Finally, if you pass, you go to the Superday where you have a couple of technical face-to-face interviews.
Interview Question 1: How would you analyse the risk of buying X company in a certain context?

Process: First meeting with directors and HR representative. Then a meeting with the regional director of the subgroup you apply to. Then, a case study and a presentation of the case study in a rating committee.
Interview Question 1: What is your opinion of X company?

Process: I Interviewed for Data Researcher I at Gurgaon office. It applied through career website. Got a link for an online test within a week or so. Then, shortlisted for the interview rounds at their office. The HR called us for orientation round. She gave a brief intro of S&P Global and explained the whole profile, salary etc. She was quite interactive. The first one was an HR round. This was a screening round. Questions were: • Tell me about yourself. • Why S&P Global Some of the candidates who were not selected were told the results after their HR interviews. Next, was Technical round. The person who took my interview was amazing. After this, they called it a day and told they will call the candidates for the next round which would be a Director interview round over call. The Director round revolved around my CV and few Finance related questions.
Interview Question 1: Derivatives, Mergers and Acquisitions,  Swaps, Credit Default Swaps, Difference between Public company and private company, Types of Derivatives

Process: I applied online and received a generic email 'Hello, I hope this email finds you well, many thanks for your recent application for the above role. Please can we arrange a time to speak in more detail, with ANOTHER ladies CV attached!!! I confirmed that I would like to have a chat even though I was a little confused as to whether it was me or the other lady whose cv was attached. A few days later, I got an email addressed to me this time with a time. The email came in at 7:01am for a 1pm telephone interview that day!! I accepted of course. I reshuffled a few meetings I had and waited. At 1:47pm I received an email saying 'Sorry. I couldn’t make this time.' I have now withdrawn my application. While it is a lovely role, there are loads of lovely roles out there. Your in-house recruiter needs some training I'd say. Firstly, GDPR people!!!!!! I'm sitting with some other persons CV in my email. Secondly, employee engagement, the human experience, candidate buy in's and first impression of the company start from the ground floor - y our recruitment team and your HR department. I have withdrawn my application as I could never work for a company that can't even show a little respect for candidates. If this is how the process of joining your company starts, I'd hate to think what it's like to work there. Standard & Poor = the Standard IS Poor!

I apllied online and then I received a call first for a phone interview to talk about what the job is abou, where they are located, and to verify some info of my curriculum. Then they ask for a 1:1 phone screen interview
Interview Question 1: What of the position interested you the most?
Interview Question 2: How do you feel about stressful situations?

Process: Interviewed for position posted on MH website. I am an employee of 3 years. Interview lasted 10-15 minutes and was told I would not be considered as I didn't have experience in the database system this dept. uses. Also told too much of a jump in wage for me! I found out the hard way that promotions are hard to come by here. We must take "baby steps". I've worked full-time for 38 years and have never had a job I could not do and do very well!
Interview Question 1: Do you have experience in this or that database?
Interview Question 2: Why are you interested in this position?

Process: My college had notified me of an opening position. McGraw normally doesn't hire editorial interns; from what I was told, almost every employee is required to start in sales so you learn their product. I followed all of the instructions I was given by the Career Services center, inlcuding emailing a cover letter and resume. I met with a woman from HR in May. The position was supposed to begin on June 1st for 3+ months and she never got back to me about the status of my application, not even a rejection email.
Interview Question 1: What do you know about our company?

Process: The interview consisted of 3 rounds The first round was a short phone interview. The final two rounds consisted of back to back interviews at their corporate office. The second round was very technical, spanning a range of macroeconomic, financial related issues. The third round was mostly behavioral, with some accounting questions asked. In total there were 5 interviewers, each occupying a different position in the firm.
Interview Question 1: Asked to rank the big 4 banks in terms of their financial sustainability. They also probed on my opinion on specific macroeconomic issues.

Process: 4 interviews (1 phone call with the HR in London / 1 in Paris with the team / 1 with the manager/ 1 with the HR in Paris to sign the contract).
Interview Question 1: #NAME?

Process: 1st round Digital interview: Quality of video was not good 2nd round Aptitude test comprise of g.k, english,reasoning, and finance section 3rd nd 4th round Personal interviewCommunication for the interview call is done by the HR to the candidate. But the status after giving the interview is not communicated properly.
Interview Question 1: Formation of company,Diversification,Questions regarding NSE,BSE

Process: it was 5 to 7 rounds, technical round , aptitude round , written, director round and at last HR round , they will give you same day the appointment letter
Interview Question 1: about derivatives , financial statements, credit default swap , Bid and ask price

Process: One hour competency based where interviewer asked prepared questions. Including background and behaviours. It was relatively straight forward and interviewed by two different internal managers with senior experience. Was a pretty organised process
Interview Question 1: Scenarios

Process: The interview process was initially very slick, especially with getting interviews set up and identifying more than one suitable role. I went on to interview for two roles with S&P, and 6 weeks later I am still yet to receive any feedback on both interviews, despite chasing.

Went for a walk-in interview for the role advertised 3 days back in newspaper. However, on going there I was told that walk-in interview was for other positions and not Marketing Analyst. I had travelled 250km to attend the interview. When asked to reimburse me the travelling costs, all I got was a heartless apology

Aptitude test Telephonic interview Video call Communication skills Very good fundamental and basic knowledge of finance and Accounts both They can call for interview at any time in the day So be prepared
Interview Question 1: basic finance and accounting

Process: Platts (McGraw-Hill) hiring is protracted and arduous. All the while it is managed by the inept and indifferent if not outright deceitful human resources department. They have several interviews and may lead you on in the belief that it''s almost over. Finally after they settle on hiring you they will take a further 3 to 4 weeks in performing background checks.
Negotiation Phase:
Absurd. There was some negotiation but make absolutely certain to get everything in writing and very explicit. 
At least two people that I know were offered reasonable bonuses which a year later turned out to be a fiction.
Interview Question 1: Tell us about a time you failed at something.

Process: more about professional stuff, specifically, knowledge and experience about financial industry, M&A process, business analytics
Interview Question 1: A case study of whether or not to acquire a company

Process: Phone screen. Met with hiring manager. 3rd interview met with various level employees.
Interview Question 1: Give me an example of a time when you ...

Process: I applied in June and went through a series of interviews with manager, publisher, president and members of other departments. The process took four months! I had one phone interview and three in-person interviews. I had to meet with two employees twice. Frankly, I think they prolonged the process so I would start in October and, therefore, not be elligible for the bonus payout the next year.
Negotiation Phase: Yes.  I was offered a low salary.  Probably one that was quite adequate for living in Columbus, but not where I lived.  I counter offered and they matched my counter offer.  I also received a signing bonus.

Process: Phone interview was a validation of credentials and expectations. Scheduled a face to face. What a fiasco. Very disorganized - no real questions asked or answers to questions given. Interviewer did not have insight into the job or expectations. Appeared as though the decision had already been made. After a very unsatisfying interview, he actually had the audacity to ask for a complete recap of both the phone interview (2 weeks previous) and the current interview, so he could pass along to the hiring manager. (As though he would not be making recommendations or screening - so why did i just waste my time?) I completed the "homework" assignment and followed up a week later - only to get an out of office/vacation auto response. I continued to follow up weekly - without response. three months + later, they declined. Really? I had always considered McGraw-Hill to be a professional org...that's why i applied. boy, was i wrong.
Interview Question 1: What do you know about McGraw-Hill
Interview Question 2: Do you have any questions about the job description

Process: phone interview, face to face interview, after that I was called in the office for final interview with the HR. then phone interview, face to face interview, after that I was called in the office for final interview with the HR. then phone interview, face to face interview, after that I was called in the office for final interview with the HR
Interview Question 1: basic questions were asked during the interview? neither too hard nor too easy

Process: Day 1:Written Test.The result was informed after 1 week via phone. Day 2:Technical Interview conducted by panel English Language Test for testing English Proficiency Finally,HR Interview which consisted of usual self introduction etc.
Interview Question 1: Formation of company,Diversification,Questions regarding NSE,BSE etc

Process: Interview for the position, hired within two weeks. Hiring manager was very nice, up front, and sharp.
Interview Question 1: Why do you want this position?

Process: The interview process has been conduct trough an online platform called HireVue. Basically, you do not have to interact with an other person, but appear 10 questions on your screen and you have to register your answers. That is why you need a device with a webcam and a microphone. The interview lasts about 30 min. It is an interesting way to take interviews, and it gives candidates the chance to peak more about their personal life and experience. There are 10 questions and you have, like 3 minutes for each.
Interview Question 1: 1. What do you know about McGraw Hill Financial and Standard and Poor's Ratings Services?
Interview Question 2: 2.Why did you apply to the program?
Interview Question 3: 3. What makes you think you are suited for the program?
Interview Question 4: 4. Which are in your opinion three personal aspects necessary to succeed in this program?

Process: Started with an HR phone interview, then the manager on the phone, then the manager and her boss in person, then a campus project with a submitted report, then met with the manger again, then a phone interview with the manager's boss, then I started to question their seriousness in me as a candidate, and I was assured this was just the process, then they flew me to NYC for interviews with the National Sales Manager and three editors. I was up against another candidate who ended up getting the job. Oddly, he lived closer to the anchor school than I. I was told if I wanted to relocate, they might have another position for me. Good luck if you are interviewing for a higher ed sales position with this company--they will keep you waiting and keep asking you to jump through hoops. I know many others who have had the same experience with McGraw-HIll.
Interview Question 1: All very routine. I was never taken off-guard. My location and drive time seemed more important then my skill set.

Process: my hiring process lasted one 3 days
Interview Question 1: they asked me a improvements to their unconscious processes

Process: First you must complete a HireVue interview. If successful, you are invited to the second round telephone interviews (2) with two S&P employees. Please note that all languages mentioned in your CV will be examined by the interviewers.
Interview Question 1: How do you relate your personal interests to your work at S&P?

Process: Nice pre screening interview- aprox 30 min talk. Interview in the company : nice people but not everything was ok. e.g Don't worry about test, a lot of people even don't start to do it it's only just to know your financial language level. bla bla bla They were looking for someone for 2 years. When I ask what's gonna be after? mhhhhhh no answer
Interview Question 1:
Why are you interested to work for McGraw?
What is your 3 good and 3 dark sides?
How you can imagine your life in next 2 years?
and etc. simple questions.

Process: Received a call from HR to introduce myself in terms of background and job experience. The HR has mixed up my application on another position and the job requirements were deceiving. The HR has promised to give me a call the day after but then she rejected that in the email.
Interview Question 1: Why do you want to apply for this role?
Interview Question 2: Can you tell the difference between S&P Rating and S&P Capital IQ?

Process: Got the opportunity through campus. Interview was held in their Hyderabad office. The process was completed in one day. Process was smooth and HR was polite. 2 rounds of interview: 1. technical 2. Interview with Department head. General discussion.
Interview Question 1:
Questions based on Accounting n Finance.
- Stock split
-Give format on income statement n Cash flow statement
- Formula of EV 
- Tell 4 types of ratios - give examples of each

Process: I applied associate program online. After two weeks, I received invitation letter and Interviewed through HireVue. It was video interview with computer. You can practice as many as you want before you actually record the interview.
Interview Question 1:
What does S&P Platts do? 
Why are you interested in commodity? 
What is your background and how does it fit to this position?

Process: Online application followed by video interview with prerecorded questions. Why S&P, education what could you contribute with. Followed by 2 telephone interviews, technical questions and personal. Then Assessment day.
Interview Question 1: Tell me the difference between the US and North Korea? Financial Statements etc.

Process: Got a 15 minute call as a preliminary screening interview after which I was called for an onsite interview. Very accomodating and the experience was great. The interview was carried out by 2 people as a panel. The questions were mostly aimed at gauging my commitment and personality. It was not a technical interview.
Interview Question 1: Why do I want to persue this post and where do I see myself in 2 years?

Process: There are 10 Video Questions followed by question regarding your university actual and expected grades. Please prepare for some of the questions that I have mentioned below to assist you in answering the video questions easily. You have to be prepared to avoid blackouts during the video sessions and keep note of the question at hand
Interview Question 1: How  do you think your academic / work experience makes you fit for the job
Interview Question 2: What do you know about S&P Global Credit Ratings
Interview Question 3: What are the 3 most important skills you feel are required to make you succeed on the job at S&P
Interview Question 4: Why do you think you are suited for this job
Interview Question 5: Do you require work authorization to work at S&P in the country you are applying. What is your current visa status

Process: Interview was scheduled to start at 09:30 am and we were supposed to reach 15 mins before, as mentioned in the interview call letter. First round was to wait for 1 hour and 30 mins as HR Haritha didn't come to office on that day. Neither she informed us anything. Later interview was started by Chaithanya at 11:00 am. I cleared technical and decided not to proceed as they told me that they were hiring full stack developers before starting the process. However interviewer said they work only in asp.net and hiring for their team only.
Interview Question 1: ASP. Net

Process: Very poor - communication was terrible from Talent Acquisition Manager. Kept rescheduling telephone interviews last minute. Time in between interviews was very long with no communication even when I followed up with calls and emails. In one face to face interview with the EMEA Talent Acquisition Director he was very disengaged. Kept looking at his two mobile phones - checking Whatsapp messages and what looked like emails. No real structure to his interview, not really many questions asked. He then left me for 15 minutes whist he looked for someone in his team to pop into meet with me. They too un prepared and unable to effectively interview - the lady spoke mostly about herself and her experience.
Interview Question 1: They tried to ask me about my experience but didn't use leading questions when trying to implement a competency based style

Process: It was good process i applied through campus recruitment and the interview process was tough including 3 rounds one was aptitude test followed by two personal interviews. The aptitude test was of 5 various domains including finance general aptitude general awareness and one statement of purpose.
Interview Question 1: Why do you want to join us?

Process: There was only on HR Round and other rounds were Analytical Test and Face to Face Interview. They asked about Merger and Acquisition. They asked abiut financial terms and financial statements
Interview Question 1: How was the Internship in MBA and What are your hobvies.About Merger and Acquisition

Process: The process took two days in which the first day includes GD round followed by the Interview round the very next day. The GD round was easy and the HR person was non biased during the group discussion. They selects the right person for the PI round. In the PI round as well the HR was very cooperative. Overall it was a nice experience for me.
Interview Question 1: They usually asks basic accounting questions and some of the questions depend upon the internship you did during your MBA.

Process: First was online test , then continued by a hr round , then technical round followed by the final round with senior manager Online test inculdes all basic aptitude verbal ability and knowledge about finance and accounting.
Interview Question 1: What do you know about s&p

Process: I had gone through the of interview for the position of Data Architect I for Islamabad office . 1st HR Screening Interview on telephone ( Introduction + JD + Technical Questions ) 2nd Online SQL test 3rd Onsite Interview (Islamabad)
Interview Question 1:
1st HR Screening Interview on telephone ( Introduction + JD + Technical Questions )
2nd Online SQL test
3rd Onsite Interview (Islamabad)

Process: Is very tuff aptitude test . But is was good experience this is very good and growthful company and we lear so many things from that things. Nice place to work

Recruitment staff made sure to walk you through the whole interview process. Series of 3 interviews - 1st with the HR staff, 2nd with the supervisor and 3rd with the hiring manager. HR staff even gave tips on what to expect for the last interview. BUT, never heard anything from the HR afterwards. I've tried to ask for updates but got no response, not even a generic message informing the candidates of the results.
Interview Question 1:
Interview with HR: typical suitability for the job questions, some questions about my resume and qualifications
Interview with supervisor and hiring manager: strength and weaknesses, technical questions and qualifications

Process: 3- 4 rounds , First round is generally HR , second is technical based on market understanding , and third is usually managerial round. round with Director of the company .
Interview Question 1: what are your strengths and weaknesses

Process: I got a mail related to exam online test ... After completing exam after three days i got phone call interview where they just checked my communication skills and told me that TI AND PI will be done in skype because of some problem I can't travel to their office so thats i requested them for skype interview so she said ok with that and she said they will send me a mail related to interview date and time .....after that there is no mail related to interview date and time till now ..and even sending them mail also i m not get any response from them ..
Interview Question 1: Normal tell me about yourself and related to basic c programming questions thats it.

Process: Aptitude test followed by SKYPE which went for about an hour. Next day i got the conformation mail by HR and offer letter shortly after confirming. Not so difficult but covered finance topics
Interview Question 1: Basic finance questions such as EPS, M&A, and other stuffs.

Process: Scheduled a call interview through text, then called on the expected time of interview. The human resource was ver considerate and patient in conducting part of the interview, given that I was in the bathroom while the interview was occurring.
Interview Question 1: What is S&P Global? What do you think we do?

Process: We had three rounds, Out of which one was technical round Second was skill test Third director interview First round consisted of all basic accounting questions Second was skill test Third round was one on one director interview
Interview Question 1: Private placement
